oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Woman in long fringed dress
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Woman with flowing hair posed in front of a bush while dressed in a long fringed dress, a beaded headband and carrying a long wooden pipe. She also wears a long necklace.
Unidentified; possibly the photographer's wife. She is wearing a fabric dress of western style and is holding the same Sioux catlinite pipe seen in #3A26084 (see scan D-05)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Two women in fringed dresses and moccasins
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Two non native young women are seated on a log dressed in fringed dresses and moccasins. The girl on the right hold a wooden pipe and wears an elaborate feathered headdress and the one on the right has on a beaded headband.
Unidentified; possibly the photographer's wife and daughter. The girl holds a Sioux catlinite pipe. Her headdress and moccasins are also of Western Indian origin.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Woman doing beadwork.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A woman sits outside her frame home at a blanket covered table and works on some beadwork. A young girl stands to the right of the table. Identified as Emma Isaac. A bead worker, she used to sell her beadwork to outlets in the Adirondack Mountain region. Child is not identified. Appears as Plate 69, in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People".

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Child in cradle board
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified child lashed into a cradle board. "Navajo Indian Baby" written along bottom of photograph. Copy stand print; tacks holding photograph are visible. Cradle boards used by the Iroquois were composed of a flat piece of wood for a back, a foot board and a hoop across the front as a means of providing shade and attaching dangling objects to keep the child's attention. The wrapped child was held firmly in the cradle board by lacing crossed in the front through holes along the edge of backboard.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wolcott, Fred Ryther, 1862-1946

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: "Pounding Corn," 1 of 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Man and woman posed in front of a frame house. Woman, wearing a white blouse and a jumper or apron, is using a wooden sifter to sift corn flour into a basin. Man wearing soft cap, shirt and tie and loose pants is using a wooden pestle to grind corn into flour in a tree stump mortar. A small white dog, barrels, buckets and stone jars are also visible in photograph. D-16 written in lower left corner. Identified as Eli Scanandoah, right, pounding corn with traditional wood mortar & pestle. unidentified woman sifting the corn flour. Appears as Plate 70 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People". Slightly closer view than scan D-003

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Man in special occasion Iroquois dress
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Man poses with his right arm shoulder high, hand up with the palm facing out. He wears a flowered shirt with a belt and has a rolled blanket coming from under his left arm up across his chest and then draped over his right shoulder. His dark pants are trimmed at the bottom and have feathers and other decorations along the side seams. He is wearing decorated moccasins and a fancy headpiece and is standing in a small rocky clearing in a brush filled area. Identified as Harry Isaacs, Soh Bee Yoh. Shown wearing special occasion Iroquois dress.
Headdress is hand drawn on the glass plate negative - eyes have also been touched up. Appears as Plate 50 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."
OHA has an original print with named spelled Issac. Also see scan E-006.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Two men in Iroquois dress
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Two men, dressed in special occasion Iroquois dress, stand in a rocky clearing. Both are wearing Western Indian feathered headdresses. Man on left has a large ax by his side. Man on right has his hand on a long rifle.
Identified as Harry Isaacs on left with the ax. His uncle Bill Isaacs is on the right with the rifle. Both are dressed up in "traditional" dress. A posed photo op with props from the photographer's collection. See scan E-005 for single view of Harry Isaacs and scan E-008 for another view of Bill Isaacs.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Woman with long black hair
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Woman with long black hair sits in grassy area. Unidentified young woman is wearing a western style man's cloth shirt with a large beaded necklace, a white skirt, and a feathered Iroquois headdress of the period. She is holding a wooden bow and two arrows. Bow and arrow show western/Plains influence and are probably from Wolcott's collection. Small building in background has large sign on side. "Limit ... Barnum....??" Can also see back of frame house. Appears as Plate 44 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Bearded man
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Older bearded man sits on wooden stool in a grassy area near some flowering trees. Telephone pole visible in background. He is holding what looks like a baseball bat upright on his right knee and wearing a large feathered headdress that trails on ground. His shirt is decorated with buttons and badges, his pants are fringed and he is wearing lace up boots. Adding pins and brooches to clothing was very popular among the Iroquois. Negative overexposed at bottom. There are pieces of wood fanned out on ground that are in the overexposed portion of the photograph. Identified as Bill Isaacs. Shown wearing his special occasion Iroquois dress popular at the time. The feathered headdress with long "tail" shows the plains Indian influence. Also see scan E-006. Appears as Plate 54 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wolcott, Fred Ryther, 1862-1946

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Pointing man wearing large feathered headpiece
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A man posed in a thicket wearing a large feathered headpiece with a long tail. He is pointing with his left arm and carrying a large war club in his right hand, He has decorated armbands near the elbows of his shirt, an open beaded vest and pants with dark stripes down the front of the leg. He is straddling some brush. Identified as Adam Jones, (Taw-nenh-doe-wenhs or "He splits the hemlocks"). A posed stereotypical photograph. Western Indian garb probably from Wolcott's collection. His personality originated the modern Onondaga term "He got Adam!" meaning "he became obstinate" or "he began to pout & quit like Adam." Jones posed for a sculpted bust on display at NY State Museum. OHA has print with caption "Chief Two Moons." Appears as Plate 42 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Woman and two men in special occasion dress
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Woman and two men in special occasion dress and headdresses pose with a large bark tray, a small bark canoe and wampum. Man in the middle sits in a wooden chair while other two sit or kneel on the grass. Identified as Melinda Johnson (left), Albert Cusick (center) & Phillip Green (right). All are wearing Iroquois special occasion dress for the period. Johnson is holding a bark tray. Cusick is holding a bunch of Wampum strings (a traditional form of record keeping) and wearing a powder horn at his waist. The design of the fabric on his collar of his shirt evolved from military uniforms. There is a model of a bark canoe at Green's feet. Photo also in OHA files. Used on the cover and as Plate 71 of "Onondaga: Portrait of a People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Man posed in a thicket wearing a large headband with two feathers, a beaded open vest, an armband near the elbow of his shirt sleeves and pants with a dark stripe down the front of the leg. He is holding a very large war club in his right hand. Identified as Adam Jones (Taw-nenh-doe-wenhs or "He splits the hemlocks"). A posed stereotypical photograph. Western Indian garb probably from Wolcott's collection. His personality originated the modern Onondaga term "He got Adam!" meaning "he became obstinate" or "he began to pout & quit like Adam." Jones posed for a sculpted bust on display at NY State Museum. Appears as Plate 53 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Jaris Pierce in feathered headdress
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A clean-shaven man dressed in dark clothing poses in front of a pile of split firewood in a wooden shelter. He is wearing a feathered headdress with the ends draped over his chest and is holding a war club in his left hand. His arms are crossed over his chest. A dark coat hangs on a wooden crossbar off to his left and an overturned bucket lies near his feet. Identified as Jaris Pierce, an Onondaga farmer. He stands near a smokehouse wearing a Plains Indian headdress and carrying a mock Iroquois war club. In 1882 Pierce was involved in unsuccessful attempts to form a constitutional government on the reservation. Appears as Plate 52 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Logan Family in front of hewn timber home
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Frank Logan's family posed in front of his hewn timber home. Three women, four children and a dog are in front of the hewn timber cabin. One woman is using a large wooden pestle and mortar. Identified as (foreground) Nancy(?) Logan his wife, seen pounding corn. Back row (left to right) Hatti Logan, ?, Frank Logan Jr., Ellen Logan (ID as Eliza Logan, 1997), Emma Logan (Ah le skwid), Nancy Logan's mother (this information on last person was reported to be incorrect by John Gibson in 1997 from research he was doing with his family). Hewn timber cabins were becoming rare at this time. Style borrowed from English colonists & were popular in the late 1780's following establishment of reservation. Appears as Plate 22 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Red Jacket's Monument
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Red Jacket's Monument on Cayuga Lake. Plaque on front reads: "RED JACKET SA-GO-YA-WAT-HA (He keeps them awake)" The orator of the six nations of Iroquois. A chief of the wolf clan of the Senecas. Born near this spot 1760; died at Buffalo 1830. Second view of monument found in scan E-075. Representatives who attended the dedication of the monument are found at scan E-018

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Methodist Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Single story white frame church with bell tower surrounded by a white picket fence. It displays a Greek Revival form.
Identified as the Methodist Church, Onondaga Indian Nation. Built in 1848 and remodeled in 1885. The church was located across the road from the school. It appeared in the Feb,17, 1872 issue of Harpers Weekly.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two women, three children and a man pose by staircase going up the side of frame house. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: People in front yard of small frame house
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three women and six men are posed near a small frame house. The women are standing on the front steps with a cat. The men are standing in the yard. This house is believed to belong to Lucy Pierce. It follows the scale of the early 19th century log cabin from which it evolved. Third man from right may be Ulie Pierce. OHA identifies this house as the Andrew Pierce home which is also see in scan E-034. Appears as Plate 40 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Man and woman posed against large boulder
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Couple posed against a large boulder in a wooded area. She is standing looking over photographer's right shoulder while the man half sits on the stone and looks at the woman. Woman wears a long dark skirt and jacket with flowing sleeves. Her blouse is white with a high collar and a thin tie. She also is wearing a stylish black hat. Clean-shaven man wears a suit with a white shirt and small bow tie. Identified as Hiram Jones (Haw wen daw na wenh or "Mild Day") with an unidentified woman. Appears as Plate 3 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Family group posed on the front steps of a frame house
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Family group posed on the front steps of a frame house. Man is seated with two women to the left and one holding a hat to the right. Small boy in suit with ruffled shirt sits by his feet.
Identified as (standing) Cecelia White (Mohawk?) Seated is Lilly Green (who became the wife of Rev. Livingston Crouse, longtime pastor of the Methodist Church, and mother of Helen Crouse), Amos Jones, Maggie White Tarbell (Mohawk) and the small boy is Eddie Jones (half uncle of Helen Crouse). Appears as Plate 20 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: George family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two men, four women, a boy and a girl posed in the grass at the side of a white frame building. Women are all in long dark skirts and light colored blouses. Girl wears a short white dress, dark stockings and lace up shoes. Men and boy wear suits. Boy carries a straw flat brimmed hat. Identified as the George Family beside the Wesleyan Methodist Church. First row (left to right) Maggie George, wife of Henry George; Phoebe George, wife of Dan George; Carl George; Iva George, unidentified woman. Second row: Henry George, a lay minister of the WMC and brother of Dan George; Dan George, uncle of Dorothy Williams; Ida George, niece of Phoebe George. Appears as Plate 12 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: The Dan George family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Posed along the side of an unpainted frame house are three women standing behind a seated man. Women are all in high necked blouses and long skirts. Man wears a white jacket, dark pants. His hat is on the ground leaning against his wooden chair.
Identified as "The Dan George Family". Seated: Dan George. Standing: Susan Crouse, Ida Williams, mother of Dorothy Williams, Lucinda George (ID from John Gibson 7.26.1994). The three women are sisters

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Gathering at Pierce home
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Five women and two boys pose in front of a white frame house. Boys are wearing suits and standing behind the women on the front steps. Four women, all in long dark skirts stand behind an older seated woman. Identified as: Seated: Lucy Pierce. Front row: Lilly Big Knife, Melinda Jacobs, Eleanor Jacobs, widow (possibly Polly LaForte (ID from John Gibson 7.26.1994). Back row: Leonard Jacobs, Ernest Jacobs. Photograph taken upon return from church. Full view of house can be seen in scan E-024. Titled in OHA collection as "Gathering at the Pierce home possibly upon returning from church." Appears as Plate 5 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: The Baptiste Lyons Family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Man, woman and young girl are posed on the edge of the front porch of a frame house. Woman wears a long white dress with ruffled hem. Dress has a dark bow around waist and a high neck. Man is wearing striped jersey and little girl has on a white dress. Identified as "The Baptiste Lyons Family". Baptiste Lyons, Rita Lyons (Peters), his wife Clara Smith Lyons (half aunt of Amanda Tomlinson. Baptiste is wearing the jersey of the reservation football team. Taped on plate "____ & Mrs. Baptise Lyon and daughter". Appears as Plate 14 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description:

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Frank Logan, Lacrosse stick maker
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Younger man with black mustache sits in a bent wood chair with an unfinished lacrosse stick resting across his lap. He is wearing a light colored shirt, dark suspenders and light colored pants. He is sitting under a large tree. Ground lower left washes out in scan. Identified as Frank Logan, Lacrosse stick maker. Logan was Tahdadaho at the time this photograph was taken. He is holding an unfinished Lacrosse stick and is seated in an Adirondack-style chair. Both commonly made at Onondaga at the turn of the century. Appears as Plate 64 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eighteen men and a boy pose by the side of a white frame building. Many are wearing striped jerseys with a big "O" on front. 1902 written at bottom of print. Identified as a Football team: Front row, left to right: Welcome Powless (Daw yu who daw ga yer day or the Trees and the bushes you can hear them coming) father of Chief Irving Powless Sr.; Joshua Scanandoah, uncle of Sarah Scanandoah, Gonyea; UID; Davis Green (?); Alec Jones. Second row: Eddie Thomas; Howard Hill(?); Sidney Issacs, father of Elsie Logan; Mose Logan, team manager; Abner Harrison(?); UID; UID. Back row: UID; Adam Thomas; Ulie Pierce(?); Ike Lyons; Baptiste Lyons, father of Rita Lyons Peters; Newton Green; Bill Beckman, uncle of Spencer Beckman & Lavinia Crane. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eleven people gathered next to a garden full of peonies. in full bloom Four men, four children and three seated women. Woman on right is seated in a "rustic chair". House with Victorian details visible in background. Identified as the Jaris Pierce Home. Jaris Pierce, in background in vest, was a successful farmer. Liza Pierce, seated left. Nellie Thomas (?) seated center. Ester & Lois Cook, children standing center. Jaris identification questioned by John Gibson 7.26.1994. Appears as Plate 31 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Backyard gathering
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Seven children, seven women and two men are posed in the yard next to a frame house. Can see open back shed with a table and some pans and buckets. One girl and three boys are sitting on the ground. The middle boy is holding a dog. Identified as a backyard gathering . Thomas LaFort, seated on right (minister of Wesleyan Methodist Church), seated next to him is Mary Big Bear, to the left of her is Sally George. Daniel Hill, standing in the middle (he is listed as a wheelwright in a wagon shop in 1910 census), and Libbie Johnson Homer, the child standing on the left. Nancy Farmer Logan is standing, back row left. Appears as Plate 2 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Three men in Iroquois dress
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Hewlett Jacobs (left), Charlie Green (center), and Albert Cusick, Onondaga-Tuscarora (right). All three are wearing Iroquois special occasion dress of the period. Jacobs is holding a gourd rattle and is wearing the traditional Iroquois headdress, (a ga sto we). Green, a chief, is holding a ceremonial Council pipe. Cusick, posed with metal tomahawk, was a former warrior chief of the Six Nations until 1896, when he renounced his title to become a Episcopal minister on the Nation. He present the pipe to NY State Museum in 1911
Scratched on bottom of negative (L-R) "Everick, Green, Jacobs." Names do not agree with the description that we have. Appears as Plate 43 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: View of northern portion of Onondaga Nation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of the northern portion of the Onondaga Nation with the Council House area in the foreground. The Council House is the large, white building in the center, the Soup House immediately to its left, Jake's Hall (Suicide Inn) is the large two story building to its right. Appears as Plate 25 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Crowd of men and children on porch
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Large crowd of men gathered on the porch and in the yard of a house to the north of the Council House across the road. Four children sit on the grass in front of the white fence that runs along the road. Apparently the photograph was taken after a lacrosse game as there are several men wearing striped jerseys and carrying lacrosse sticks. Appears as Plate 41 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Large crowd of people gathered in front of a frame church with a square bell tower. Identified as the Wesleyan Methodist Church at the Onondaga Nation built in 1895. Hatless figure in center front is Rev. Thomas LaFort, founder. Appears as Plate 27 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Mose Logan
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two women, two children and two men posed with two horses in front of a frame house. Identified as the Mose Logan Family on the Beckman Homestead. Left to right: Molly Beckman, her sisters Lilly Beckman Logan (wife of Mose Logan) & Harriett Beckman; Mose Logan (son-in-law to Lucien Beckman), Logan child, Lucien Beckman, holding horses, married to Melissa Beckman & grandfather of Spenser Beckman and Lavinia Beckman Crane. Note camera bag in image's foreground. This farm is a typical reservation farm of the period. "Mose Logan" scratched on bottom of plate. Appears as Plate 24 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Man in front of Elementary School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Man stands by the white picket fence surrounding a two story white frame building. Dirt road runs along fence in front of school. The Elementary school on the Onondaga Nation. This school, built in 1915, was constructed on the site of the original school which had burned in 1913 after 26 years of use. This building burned in 1937 and was replaced by the present brick school house. Appears as Plate 39 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Harvest scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two men stand in a field of shocked corn stalks and pumpkins, traditional crops that were common at the time of the photograph. Shadow of the photographer can be seen. Identified as a Harvest Scene at the Onondaga Nation. Unidentified; Wilson Johnson. Appears as Plate 65 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Newton Green
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Man dressed in western style clothing with a holstered gun on his hip and a feathered headdress is posed with a horse in front of a white frame house. Small child holds a long rifle while a women and two children wait by the side of the house. Identified as Newton Green and family. Newton is wearing western Indian style clothing made of fabric and a western style feathered headdress. Note that the shirt is worn over a white shirt, sweater and tie. The costume, .22 rifle & pistol are probably props owned by the photographer. Photo taken in front of Newton Green's mother's house.
"Newton Green" scratched on right side of glass negative. Appears as Plate 49 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Lacrosse team
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Twenty Lacrosse players wearing striped jerseys and holding lacrosse sticks are posed next to a white frame building. Man in the center of the middle row wears a Plains Indian headdress. Identified as - front row: (left to right) Jesse Lyons, Eddie Logan(?), Ike Lyons, David Torrence(?). Second row: Howard Hill (?), Ulie Pierce(?), Mose Logan (team Manager), UID, Sidney Logan, Eddie Thomas, UID. Back row: Newton Green (asst. manager), UID, UID,UID, Adam Thomas, UID, Adam Jones, Bill Beckman, John Isaacs, "1904" scratched on plate so dates do not match. Appears as Plate 51 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People." Appears on front cover of "American Indian Sports Heritage" by Joseph B. Oxendine

Identified as the Home of David R. Hill, the manager of the reservation's cornet band. Appears as Plate 23 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Simple church with square bell tower has a vertical board and batten siding. A large house is located next to the church. Identified as the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd, Onondaga Indian Reservation. It appeared in the Feb. 17, 1872 issue of Harpers Weekly. Appears as Plate 33 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Nineteen young men
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nineteen young men posed by the side of a white frame building. Most a wearing striped jerseys. Man seated second from left in middle row hold a football that has 1904 painted on it. Upper right corner of glass negative has been broken off and is missing. Football team: Reclining in front, left John Isaacs; Leonard Jacobs (?), right. Front row: UID; Newton Green; Sidney Isaacs; Ike Lyons; Eddie Jones; Mose Logan, team manager; Joshua Scanandoah, assistant team manager(?). oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Will Johnson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A young man in a fringed deerskin outfit, wears a headpiece with long dangling side pieces and single feather. He has a weapon tucked in his belt and is holding a long rifle while standing next to a horse. His horse has a braided bridle and reins with trim at the brow piece and bit. Identified as Will Johnson, a farmer. He is posed in 'western' style dress with a percussion rifle. The costume & rifle are probably from Wolcott's collection. 'Will Johnson' scratched on left side of the glass plate negative. A copy of this photograph exists in the Onondaga Historical Association's collection. Appears as Plate 48 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three people on the Upper Hemlock Road area of the Onondaga Nation. Unidentified man is standing with his hat in his hand; Melinda Johnson sits in the grass; Albert Cusick is pointing to something. He is wearing traditional clothing. Written on edge of plate 'Bird's eye view of the Onondaga Res. 1902'. Appears as Plate 45 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Baptiste Thomas
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Older man with white handlebar mustache and goatee. He is wearing a wide brimmed black hat, a white shirt with suspenders and dark pants. There is a watch chain draped across the front of his pants just below the waistband. He is standing near the side of a frame house. Identified as Baptiste Thomas (Sa ha whi). He was married to Emma LaForte. He made a translation of the Hiawatha tradition included in book The Constitution of the Five Nations by AC Parker. OHA has an original print. Date courtesy of OHA. Bottom half of glass negative is missing. Top half shows large crack. Appears as Plate 17 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Man and woman
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Man and woman posed by the side of a frame building. Man is clean-shaven and wearing a three piece suit with a white shirt and bow tie. He stands to the left of seated woman wearing a print blouse with long sleeves and a high neck. Blouse has dark ribbon trim at neck, yolk and wrists. Her long skirt is also white or light colored.Identified as Jesse Lyons, a laborer in a saw mill & his wife Julia. Backing taped on negative because the emulsion was flaking off. Poor quality scan. Appears as Plate 4 in Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Gibson family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Woman, four children and a baby are posed around another young girl seated in a wooden chair along the side of a frame house. Onondaga Indians is scratched on top of glass negative which is in very poor condition. Image of baby in mother's arm has lost its face and image of the girl standing just in front of the baby has had her face laid back on the negative. Identified as 'The Gibson Family'. Victoria Gibson, mother, standing back row right. Back row: Frank Gibson, Margaret Johnson, Victoria Gibson, Andrew Jr., son of Andrew Gibson Sr. Seated in chair is Louise Gibson, Rebecca Gibson next to her. (ID from John Gibson 7.26.1994). Appears as Plate 18 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Onondaga Nation: Baseball team
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eleven men posed on the front porch of a frame house. Ten are wearing uniforms. Crossed bats, gloves and baseball on ground in front of the Baseball Team. Man in dark clothing stands center back row,Identified as - in the foreground: Emmett Lyons. First row, seated on steps, UID (left), Jessie Lyons (right). Third row: Ike Lyons; Alec Jones; David Torrence (?); Eddie Jones; Bill Beckman. Standing: Elmer Printup; Mose Logan, (team manager); UID. Emulsion is flaking off the glass negative and a backing has been taped to the plate. A print of this photo located at OHA is dated 1912. A copy stand print, D-15, of this image also appears in this collection. Appears as Plate 55 in "Onondaga: Portrait of a Native People."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sharrer's Store in 1895
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sharrer's Store in 1895 - 300 block of First Street, Liverpool, N.Y. - south side - two houses visible behind the store on left - Store is two stories tall with staircase going up left side of building. 2 men are sitting on roof - team of horse & buckboard are standing in front of the store. Unpaved street with 6 adults and 14 children posed on the steps of the store or in the street near wagon. Store sign says "_.F. Sharrer Provisions - Flour & Feed. Boots - Shoes - Crocker Y&C". Smaller signs for Meat Market and Public telephone. JT Rogers photography studio located upstairs, display of photographs seen at bottom of stairs. See CCH00002 for a later picture of this building.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Two story Fruit & Confectionery store with ice cream parlor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two story building - Sign reads Fruit & Confectionery - smaller sign on house at back reads: Ice Cream Parlor. Man and woman are in front of the ice cream shop. -This is the pre-Sharrer's Store - 300 block of First Street - Board sidewalk and dirt road visible. House on right side, open lot on left. Door leading up to JT Rogers photography studio on right side of porch with display of photographs by door. Note that the entrance to Mr. Rogers' studio is on the right of the building in this photograph. It was later moved to the left side of the building and entrance to the studio was gained by an outdoor staircase. See CCH00001 for a later picture of this building.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Trinity Evangelical Church, Liverpool
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Trinity Evangelical Church - built in 1886 - corner of Vine & Hazel Streets. It burned and was remodeled in 1932. Trinity Church of the Evangelical Association was formed in 1844 and a small church was built on Salina Street. In 1849 the congregation moved to 506 Oswego Street where they stayed until 1886. A new wooden church was built in 1886 on the corner of Hazel & Vine Streets and painted pink. The Evangelical congregation disbanded in 1939 and in 1942 the church building was purchased by an Episcopal congregation. It became an Episcopal Church in 1942 and burned to the ground in 1954. Winter scene.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Rogers, James T.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Churches; Architecture; Winter
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Print - glossy; b/w; Glass plate #10; large negative #10; small negative page 10 row 2/9 ;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: National Hotel, Liverpool
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The National Hotel (later known as the Cobblestone) built in 1839. It was built from a design of H. and W. Clark in 1839 and was built by Jonathan Hicks. Many of the stones used in the structure were drawn from Lake Ontario. The walls of the building are 3 feet thick. This building later housed The Cobblestone Tavern. Tulip Street view of side of building. Horse and wagon tied up near back porch. 5 men and 7 boys gather near open doorway. Man lying on his side on the stone mounting block. Sign on post near front of building says: National Hotel. First Street in front of the hotel is unpaved and tree lined. Note hitching post located at corner of sidewalks in foreground. Edge of building seen on right side of picture housed a livery stable.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Rogers, James T.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hotels; Architecture; Villages; People; Carts & wagons; Horses; Hitching posts

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Balezhauser's Hotel, Liverpool
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Balezhauser's Hotel, 309 First Street, Liverpool. Later became Tarby's Restaurant. Sign on right. Building was torn down in 1973 and land was paved for a parking lot. Note the two story outhouse on right side of image and water pump located along edge of unpaved First Street. Brick building to left was later altered to a one story and now houses Nichols Liquor Store. Woman standing on upper balcony. Two men posed at street level and a third man visible at top of stairs on right. Current location - Nichols Grocery Store parking lot next to Liquor Store. Different angle and later time period than print number CCH00122

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gleason Mansion, Liverpool
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Gleason Mansion - 314 Second Street, Liverpool, NY. Very early print, pine tree in side yard. Originally built in 1857 by Liverpool millionaire Lucius Gleason, the home was restored in 1994-95 and is listed on the State and National Registers of Historic Places. The house is a stucco-on-brick Italianate design. Woman seen sitting on front porch. Side walks are cement. Photo ca. 1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Miller, George Waxy
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mansions; Architecture; Sidewalks; Pines; Porches

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Salt boiling in a saddle block, 1 of 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior of Salt Industry Boiling Blocks, Village of Liverpool.Looking down the center brine pipeline in a boiling block. On the left side baskets of draining salt sit next to the kettles where it was boiled. George Dow and Jacob Frank are the men in the image. One man stands on left side with a basket of salt at the entrance to one of the drying bins built into sides of the boiling block. There is another basket of salt on a wheel barrow right behind him. On the right side two baskets hold salt and the rest are still empty. A second man, wearing an apron, is leaning over the kettles with his hand on the plug to the spout that fills the kettle. Note the wooden handle of the scoop used to take salt out of the kettles and place it in the baskets to drain. A wheelbarrow is visible in the aisle behind him. This is a salt saddle block with weighted pulleys in foreground that were used to open or close the fire doors in the furnaces located below. There is no visible steam so the fires are out and the kettles are cold. Also see image CCH00074.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Rogers, James T.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Salt industry; Salt; Pipelines; Baskets; Wheelbarrows; Pulleys; Laborers; Clothing & dress;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Salt boiling in a saddle block, 2 of 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior of Salt Industry Boiling Blocks, Village of Liverpool. Looking down the center brine pipeline in a boiling block. On the left side baskets of draining salt sit next to the kettles where it was boiled. Man on left is posed next to a wheelbarrow holding two baskets of salt in front of the drying bins built into the side of the boiling block. Man on right is wearing an apron and using a long handled scoop to take salt out of the kettle and place it in the baskets to drain. A wheelbarrow is in aisle behind him. George Dow and Jacob Frank are the men in the image. This is a salt saddle block with weighted pulleys in foreground that were used to open or close the fire doors in the furnaces located below. There is no visible steam so the fires are out and the kettles are cold. Print made from original glass plates by J.T. Crawford in 1976. Also see image CCH00073.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mud Lock on the Oswego Canal
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Five men, one child and a woman driving a 2 wheel gig pose in front of the store at Mud Lock on the Oswego Canal. "Frank(?)" written on on roof of porch - may be Frank Wise. Note small boat on porch and construction of the lock. To pass from the Oswego Canal into the Seneca River, or vice versa, a boat had to pass through Mud Lock which was restored in the 1930s during the building of Onondaga Lake Park. View is looking NE at Frank Wise's Hotel, formerly operated by Charlie Parker. The bar was in the one story ell. Ballroom, dining room and kitchen were on the first floor. There were four bedrooms and a sitting room on the 2nd floor. Many dances and parties were held here and it was a popular destination for sleighriders from Liverpool. Left to right: Jim Cronk of Liverpool, Billy Rose (a pensioner who had a shack at Mudlock), Jess Kinney of Liverpool, Frank Wise (former lock tender with dog Jerry), Sachs Ziegler, Agnes Wise, Mrs. O.W. Oberlander in Dr. Oberlander's road cart. Identifications are from OHA
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Locks (Hydraulic engineering); Canals; People; Carriages & coaches; Boats; Dogs

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Wiegand & John Klippert, Liverpool willow weavers, look at an unfinished laundry basket in a Salt Museum exhibit. Note iron frame holding up the willow whips.
